unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip to India, awesome! Finding the perfect place to stay can be a bit of a headache, right? Let's talk addresses. Seriously, decoding an Indian address can feel like cracking a code. You'll see everything from concise abbreviations to seemingly endless strings of numbers and street names. Don't worry, it's not rocket science. This is the blog to help you prepare, you can thank me later!
normalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip to India, awesome! Finding the perfect place to stay can be a bit of a headache, right? Let's talk addresses. Seriously, decoding an Indian address can feel like cracking a code. You'll see everything from concise abbreviations to seemingly endless strings of numbers and street names. Don't worry, it's not rocket science. This is the blog to help you prepare, you can thank me later!

unnormalised: First things first, understand the basics. A typical address is a little like this: "House No. 123, 4th Cross, MG Road, Bangalore, 560001, Karnataka, India." "House No." speaks for itself, often shortened to "No." or "#". The "Cross" bit? That refers to the intersecting street. "MG Road" is obviously the main road. And then comes the pin code or postal index number. Pay close attention to this. It is *crucial*. 560001 is for you Bangaloreans!
normalised: First things first, understand the basics. A typical address is a little like this: "House Number one hundred and twenty three, fourth Cross, M-G Road, Bangalore, five hundred and sixty thousand and one, Karnataka, India." "House Number" speaks for itself, often shortened to "Number" or "hash". The "Cross" bit? That refers to the intersecting street. "M-G Road" is obviously the main road. And then comes the pin code or postal index number. Pay close attention to this. It is crucial. five hundred and sixty thousand and one is for you Bangaloreans!

unnormalised: Now, booking hotels online can be a real time-saver. Sites like Booking.com, MakeMyTrip, and Agoda are your friends. When booking, they’ll usually ask for the full address. Hotel addresses often look like this: "The Taj Mahal Palace, Apollo Bunder, Colaba, Mumbai, 400001, Maharashtra." Notice "Apollo Bunder" and "Colaba?" Specific landmarks or neighbourhoods. Super helpful for your taxi or auto-rickshaw driver.
normalised: Now, booking hotels online can be a real time-saver. Sites like Booking dot com, MakeMyTrip, and Agoda are your friends. When booking, they’ll usually ask for the full address. Hotel addresses often look like this: "The Taj Mahal Palace, Apollo Bunder, Colaba, Mumbai, four hundred thousand and one, Maharashtra." Notice "Apollo Bunder" and "Colaba?" Specific landmarks or neighborhoods. Super helpful for your taxi or auto-rickshaw driver.

unnormalised: Sometimes, especially with smaller guesthouses or homestays, the address might be… less precise. Like, "Near the Big Hanuman Temple, Gokarna, Karnataka." In those cases, having the phone number is a life-saver. Call ahead and get clearer directions. Use Google Maps, but don’t rely on it blindly. Indian roads can be… unpredictable.

In those cases, having the phone number is a life-saver. Call ahead and get clearer directions. Use Google Maps, but don’t rely on it blindly. Indian roads can be… unpredictable.

unnormalised: Don't be surprised if you see alternate spellings. "Bengaluru" and "Bangalore" are the same city, but different spellings. Similarly, "Mumbai" was Bombay not so long ago. Always check the PIN code. This will resolve ambiguity.
normalised: Don't be surprised if you see alternate spellings. "Bengaluru" and "Bangalore" are the same city, but different spellings. Similarly, "Mumbai" was Bombay not so long ago. Always check the P-I-N code. This will resolve ambiguity.

unnormalised: Also, keep an eye out for local landmarks in the address. For example, an address might say "Opposite SBI Bank, Sector 17, Chandigarh, 160017." That SBI bank is your point of reference. Tell the driver, "Bhaiya, Sector 17, SBI bank ke saamne."
normalised: Also, keep an eye out for local landmarks in the address. For example, an address might say "Opposite S-B-I Bank, Sector seventeen, Chandigarh, one hundred and sixty thousand and seventeen." That S-B-I bank is your point of reference. Tell the driver, "Bhaiya, Sector seventeen, S-B-I bank ke saamne."

unnormalised: When providing your address to a hotel for delivery or other purposes, be very specific. Include your room number! Something like "Room No. 302, Hotel Grand Central, 12 Park Street, Kolkata, 700016, West Bengal." The room number is essential to ensure you receive whatever it is you may be receiving at the hotel.
normalised: When providing your address to a hotel for delivery or other purposes, be very specific. Include your room number! Something like "Room Number three hundred and two, Hotel Grand Central, twelve Park Street, Kolkata, seven hundred thousand and sixteen, West Bengal." The room number is essential to ensure you receive whatever it is you may be receiving at the hotel.

unnormalised: Another thing, when booking train tickets, you might need to enter the address of your destination. Again, be as detailed as possible. "C/O Rakesh Sharma, 10/2, Ballygunge Circular Road, Kolkata, 700019." "C/O" means "care of," meaning Rakesh Sharma lives at this address and he will be the one receiving you.

"Care of Rakesh Sharma, ten divided by two, Ballygunge Circular Road, Kolkata, seven hundred thousand and nineteen." "Care of" means "care of," meaning Rakesh Sharma lives at this address and he will be the one receiving you.

unnormalised: Remember, Indian addresses can be a bit of a wild ride, but a little preparation can save you a ton of stress. Double-check the pin code, look for landmarks, and don’t hesitate to call ahead for clearer directions.
